displayed_text: Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Uh, that would be great! If, you know, uh, we don’t see it - more, it is a zero. The testosterone has recovered. That would be ideal. Um. The next step is, you know, that we don’t get rid of your cancer with all of this and that your PSA goes up in the future. And, is that a longer time to get to that point or is it sort of like, even if we just did one thing, it’s all on-time? Patient: I do have one question. The, the rib. (pause) Doctor: Uh, because, we, we don’t normally cut out the ribs. I mean, that’s where we’re gonna offer radiation to that spot. Patient: Right, right. Doctor: So, that’s gonna treat that spot. Patient: And that would be later after the chemo cycles. Doctor: So, right. So, we start the hormones. We get you chemotherapy. We give you a little bit of a break. I don’t know if it’s a month- Healthcare Professional: Mm Hmm. Doctor: And then you have your surgery. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: And then, based on what we see under the microscope, they can discern whether or not we’re gonna give you radiation to your prostate to try to clean up the area or is it all pretty decent. And, then they can plan the spot radiation to the sites that we’ve seen before. (pause) Patient: Yeah, it was a lymph node and

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, but that would be another possibility, I think, uh- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: -that we could consider. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, if you’re, uh, again, the easiest thing is going to be to do the hormone therapy straight up. Patient: Right. Right. Doctor: So, uh, we could potentially do the hormone therapy and then do the vaccine, also. Okay? Patient: Right. Doctor: So, uh. Patient: What did you think about that? Because I know you think differently than I do. Doctor: And so the Xtandi trials we have are Xtandi plus, uh, one of the drugs affect kind of the hormone pathways in different ways. Uh, so there’s some reason why they would work together with Xtandi. Uh, one of them is an immune drug itself. Uh, that immune drug, that, that trial, you get either the Xtandi plus the immune drug or just the Xtandi alone, but it requires biopsy. Uh, the other, the other trial we have is Xtandi plus, uh, a drug that affects we think a signal that the cancers can use as an alternative to the hormone signal. So they kind of switch over. So our idea is to block both signals to see if that would help. That, I think you get both drugs, uh, but, again, it also requires a biopsy. Family Member: Right.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: It could be a cancer spot. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Or it could be that you bled into your adrenal gland, and so, uh, hemorrhaged into the adrenal gland. Was that your aspirin? You know, I don’t know why people do that. But you can spontaneously do that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. Is it a side effect of the drug? I don’t know. But is it a cancer spot? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. So, let’s go to the data. You are on therapy, really tolerating it okay? Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: And I would say, no worse for the wear? Patient: Nope. Doctor: Um, we have scans that are sort of trending worse but nothing definitively worse --- by new other than the adrenal thing, and that is hedging. Patient: Okay.

Patient: I I think sh-she wants to um call for me. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Yup. Mhm. Doctor: Alright, so I will be in touch with you as soon as I have that, the result. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Nice to see you again. Patient: Same here. Doctor: Thank you. Patient: socks. Doctor: I know. Doctor: I’ll be wearing it next time.

Patient: Alright. How have you been? Doctor: Hi. Nice to see you. Family Member: Nice to see you. Doctor: Hey, Mr. ___. Patient: How you been doing? You alright? Doctor: I’m alright. Not too bad. So how did you heal up from the pneumonia in the hospital? Patient: Uh, I don’t know, I guess I’d be alright. I’m back walking. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I couldn’t walk then. It got bad. Doctor: Gosh. Patient: I went to the hospital. Doctor: Yeah. Gosh. Could you, uh, uh breathe without oxygen?

Patient: February Doctor: But not since you last saw me? Patient: Oh, no. But I did take iron then, but I haven’t taken it since. So. Doctor: Have you been thinking clearly? Any issues with your – just how you process things? Patient: No. (Clicking) Doctor: Anything new on your body today? Rashes? Skin changes? Patient: No. Doctor: Swelling? Bumps, Lumps? Patient: No. No. Family Member: Are those, uh, energy drinks that you see on TV problematic? I’m asking sort of for myself, too. Doctor: Uh. I mean they have a lot of calories in them, and so, uh, it’s more about why he’s takin’ them or Family Member: Oh, okay.

Family Member: If he thinks of it he can get it anywhere he is. Patient: Because I drink water. I like water. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: You’re gonna have to make it an effort then get in to see the nephrology folks… Patient: Okay. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: … ‘cause you’re at that you know anywhere from like one-six to one-nine and it’s not that big of a jump. Patient: Right. Doctor: But then if you get over two and things like that life gets harder. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Then you’re straining that one kidney bean too much. Patient: Right.

Patient: You know, I feel good. Doctor: That’s good. Let’s see and you’re sixty… Patient: No I’m fifty-nine. Doctor: Fifty-nine. Patient: I’m not sixty yet. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: It’s alright. (laughs) Doctor: Fifty-nine. And generally men under sixty have a recurrence I mean are able to have a sexual function even without medication ultimately. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: So I suspect that you’ll probably be there. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Alright? It’s still early.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay your testosterone is not as low as I would like it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s it’s low, but it should be lower ideally with the Lupron. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So your next Lupron which is tomorrow is happening with R____. Patient: Right… Doctor: Right? Patient: …and after that you guys are supposed to take it over. Doctor: Okay, alright we’ll do that. Patient: I don’t ever see Dr. R____ no more over there. Doctor: Okay.

Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: You know if this is one of five lymph nodes, and you know the other four are invisible, then you drop by twenty percent. Family Member: If it drops by twenty percent, then we’ll know okay somewhere else - Doctor: cancer; we’ll look at the majority of the cancer where eighty percent went somewhere else. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: In the meantime you’ve bought a few months, maybe a year, of not starting hormone therapy. Patient: And it’s more of a proactive approach, you know like I had my prostate removed in two thousand and seven. There was no activity until two, well for ten years. Family Member: Right. Doctor: Uh hum, right. Patient: And then all of a sudden this stuff just popped up Doctor: Yeah. Patient: as opposed to two thousand and seven if there was a thing of saying well just to make sure we cleaned up everything, let’s do like a, give us, put together some chemo and do that.

Family Member: Okay. And that’s the injection he has? Doctor: No. Family Member: No? Doctor: No. The injection he has right now is uh, the hormone therapy, the Lupron. Family Member: Yeah. Okay. Doctor: That will continue. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But we have to do something different to add on to this uh treatment. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Right now to try and control the growth and growing part of the cancer. Okay? And one way to do that is there standard treatment. So there are medications, pills, hormonal pills, that you could take at home every day, and about once a month, every two or three weeks, I will need to monitor you. So you will need somewhat closer monitoring because of that. Family Member: More visits? Doctor: Yeah. The other option is uh to go on a clinical trial which will give us both these medications, and both of these medicines are IV, but you have to come even more frequently for that. Family Member: So, like every other week or something like that?

Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Yeah. They have a room that, uh, where they would do the- Patient: You can’t tell what I’m getting? Doctor: No. No. I think we’ll, we will know if you’re getting the real thing or not. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: But, you know, we don’t have a choice. Patient: Right. Right. Doctor: So, so they randomize you to just standard treatment, then you wouldn’t get the- Patient: There’s seventy percent I will get the real thing? Doctor: Two out of three. Yes. Yeah. Patient: Hum. But, uh, for some reason I want to quit or couldn’t make anymore, I could just stop? Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. If you’re not tolerating it or if there are issues, yeah.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.neutral: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.Yes, Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::Yes, Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Prefer to self-describe (please specify): What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Prefer to self-describe (please specify)

displayed_text: Patient: Um Hmm. Doctor: -you’re coming back. Call me a little hyper-anal. Doctor: Yes. Let’s do that. Doctor: I am. Good plan. Right? Plus it’ll keep you more on track if you know that you have to come in and we check your sugars and yeppers. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That’s it. Patient: Okay. I am getting a shot today? Doctor: Um hum. Patient: And I do have it here? Doctor: I think so. Was there a question on that? Patient: I don’t know. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I wasn’t aware of-

Healthcare Professional: - after that spot. It’s… Or are you worried that it will drop the PSA and not necessarily correlate the scans? Doctor: Uh if the PSA drops it means the cancer is done. Healthcare Professional: Yes, so because it could be the PSA coming from that one area. Doctor: Right, right, correct. Healthcare Professional: And if you zap that and you see the PSA drop, that’s good. Patient: So uh hum, okay, okay. Doctor: It’s not going to drop by like ninety-nine percent. So don’t expect; with hormone therapy, that’s what usually happens - Patient: Yeah I got it. Doctor: - You get a dramatic drop. When you get a drop because cancer is dying. With this, if this was truly the only lymph node. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: You know then you would expect the PSA to drop by like ninety percent. Family Member: Uh hum.
